Description: Terracotta figure of Bes armed. He is running to the right, his body and head frontal. He wears a short tunic cinched in below his belly, and boots; most of his feathered crown is lost. In his raised right hand he brandishes his sword above his head (its tip has gone along with the crown) and he holds an oval Gaulish shield to his left side. The back is plain, with a circular vent. Hollow, made in a two-piece mould. Micaceous orange-brown Nile silt.
Curator's comments: Close parallels are dated to the second century AD (Bayer-Niemeier 1988, no. 437). Published by Gutch (in Hogarth et al. 1898-9, 95 no. 5; see also Frankfurter 1998, 125n. 98) though Bailey attributes this to the 1st to 2nd century BC (Bailey 2008, 40). Bayer-Niemeier, E. 1988, Bildwerke der Sammlung Kaufmann / Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik Frankfurt am Main I. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten, Melsungen. Frankfurter, D. 1998, Religion in Roman Egypt. Assimilation and Resistance, Princeton. Gutch, C. 1899. “The Terracottas”, in Hogarth, D. G., Edgar, C.C., “Excavations at Naukratis”, ABSA 5, 67-97.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (C608)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.211) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 95, n. 5)
Condition: The figure is broken away below the ankles.
